fact: Vending machines sell everything from live crabs to complete motorcycles.
There are more horses in Iceland than people (around 5 times more!)
The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of the world's oxygen.
The leaning Tower of Pisa is not the only leaning tower in Italy.
The Netherlands is the world's largest flower exporter.
Machu Picchu, the ancient Inca city, was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911.
The Great Wall of China is the longest man-made structure in the world.
Australia has more sheep than people (around 2.5 times more!)
Tango, the passionate dance, originated in Argentina.
The Great Migration is considered one of the greatest wildlife spectacles on Earth.
The pyramids of Giza are the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
The Olympic Games originated in ancient Greece.
The world's first ever novel, Don Quixote, was written by Miguel de Cervantes.
The French Foreign Legion is a military unit of the French Army that allows foreigners to join.
The United Kingdom is a group of four countries: England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States.
Canada has the longest coastline in the world.
The ancient Mayan city of Chichen Itza is home to the Kukulkan pyramid, also known as El Castillo.
Oktoberfest is a world-famous beer festival held annually in Munich, Germany.
Russia is the largest country in the world by land area.
Thailand is the world's second-largest producer of rubber.
Ha Long Bay, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is known for its towering limestone pillars and emerald waters.
New Zealand is known as the adventure capital of the world.
South Africa is home to Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 27 years.
Morocco is a North African country with a rich history and culture.
Chile is a long, narrow country located in South America.
Argentina is the world's largest producer of yerba mate, a caffeinated herbal drink.
Brazil is the world's leading producer of coffee.
India is a country with a rich diversity of cultures, religions, and languages.
Salar de Uyuni in Bolivia is the world's largest salt flat, stretching over 10,000 square kilometers.
Ghana is the world's second-largest producer of cocoa beans.
Indonesia is the world's most populous island nation.
Switzerland has four official languages: German, French, Italian, and Romansh.
The archipelago of Stockholm consists of over 30,000 islands.
Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world.
Flamingos are a common sight in Lake Nakuru National Park in Kenya.
Mount Everest, the world's highest mountain, is located in Nepal.
Iceland uses geothermal energy to heat a majority of its homes and buildings.
Costa Rica is considered one of the happiest countries in the world.
Mongolia has the world's lowest population density.
Finland has over 187,000 lakes, earning it the nickname 'Land of a Thousand Lakes'.
Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa.
The Nazca Lines, a series of giant geoglyphs etched into the desert, are a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Peru.
Iran is home to half of the world's pistachios.
Reggae music originated in Jamaica.
The flightless bird, the kiwi, is a national symbol of New Zealand.
Easter Island, famous for its moai statues, is part of Chile.
Pastéis de nata, a rich egg tart pastry, is a national treasure in Portugal.
Senegal is known for its vibrant music scene, particularly drumming and mbalax.
Ethiopia is the only African country to never be colonized by a European power.
Hagia Sophia, a former church, mosque, and now museum, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site that bridges the gap between Christianity and Islam.
Phở (pronounced fuh), a noodle soup, is Vietnam's national dish.
Tango lessons are a popular activity for tourists in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
The Wieliczka Salt Mine in Poland, dating back to the 13th century, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
South Korea has one of the fastest internet connection speeds in the world.
Marrakech, Morocco, is a famous destination known as the Red City for its red-colored buildings.
Ireland is known for its rich history of storytelling and pub culture.
The Galapagos Islands, known for inspiring Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, are part of Ecuador.
Colombia is the world's second most biodiverse country, following Brazil.
You can commercially bungee jump off the Kawarau Bridge, the world's first ever site for this activity.
Take a dip in the geothermal Blue Lagoon, a milky-turquoise colored pool surrounded by black lava rock.
Embark on the ultimate mountaineering challenge - conquering Mount Everest, the highest mountain in the world.
Go white-water rafting on the thrilling rapids of the Pacuare River, surrounded by lush rainforest.
Witness the awe-inspiring wildebeest migration in the Serengeti National Park, the largest mammal migration on Earth.
Take a camel trek through the vast Sahara Desert, experiencing the nomadic lifestyle under a star-filled sky.
Go spelunking in the Narusawa Ice Cave, venturing deep into a world of glistening ice formations.
Challenge yourself with the world's most dangerous road - the North Yungas Road, also known as 'Death Road'.
Iguazu Falls, on the border with Argentina, is a breathtaking series of waterfalls larger than Niagara Falls.
Go kayaking amongst breaching whales in the waters off Vancouver Island, an unforgettable wildlife encounter.
Ski down the slopes of Villarrica Volcano, an active volcano offering stunning views and thrilling descents.
Explore the maze-like tunnels of the Cu Chi Tunnels, a network used by Viet Cong guerillas during the Vietnam War.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system, offering incredible snorkeling and diving opportunities.
Traverse the breathtaking Mont Blanc massif, the highest mountain range in Western Europe, for epic scenery and challenging hikes.
Go spelunking in the Frasassi Caves, a vast network of underground chambers adorned with stunning stalactites and stalagmites.
Take a hot air balloon safari over the Maasai Mara National Reserve, spotting incredible wildlife from above.
Go cage diving with Great White Sharks in Gansbaai, experiencing these apex predators up close.
Hike the scenic trails of Trolltunga, a spectacular cliff formation jutting out over a vast lake.
Embark on the Glacier Express train journey, traveling through breathtaking Alpine scenery on one of the most scenic railways in the world.
Scuba dive the underwater ruins of Santorini, a volcanic island with remnants of an ancient civilization.
Swim with manta rays in the crystal-clear waters of Nanuya Lailai Island, a magical underwater encounter.
Hike through the ancient Mayan city of Tikal, exploring towering temples hidden within the rainforest.
